story.text: Hey, what grade are you in?
Fourth grade!
Do you like the fourth-grade?
<label>Yeah!</label> Wanna meet my classmates?
I mean, I guess…
OK! Here they are!
Wow. Thanks, kid. Mind if I ask your class a question?
Sure! But hurry up. Recess starts soon.

Who here feels like you <label>belong at the school</label>?


So, like, feeling respected by other students and supported by adults?
Those of us in <label>yellow</label> feel like we belong. Why do you ask?

Well, a sense of belonging is [really important](https://www.edweek.org/leadership/a-universal-prevention-measure-that-boosts-attendance-and-improves-behavior/2024/04). It helps you feel better and do well in school.
Let’s ask the fifth graders the same question.
Sup. Who *are* you?

Never ask that to an adult. It’s mean.


Fifth-graders, who here feels like you belong in school?
Most of us, obviously.
OK, I have more questions for everyone here.
OKAYYYYUHH!!!!
Who here has a good <label>relationship with their teachers</label>?
Who has <label>supportive relationships</label>—teachers, family members, and friends?
Who is <label>engaged in school</label>? This means you’re interested in your classes and excited about school.

Who thinks the <label>school’s climate</label> is good?


This means your teachers are excited to be here, the school building is good, and you think the rules are fair to you.

OK, last one.


Who frequently experienced <label>positive feelings</label> in the past week? Feelings like excitement, happiness, hope, love, and safety?
Are you done asking questions? School’s almost over.
Could I just talk to fifth-graders for a second?
I just want you to know that a lot is going to change in your lives in the next year.
We’re going to middle school next year! We’ll finally go to school with older kids.
Yes, that’s a huge thing but there’s a lot that’s going to change inside you.
Gross. We don’t want to talk about that…
No, no, the biggest changes will be in your brain…

About the time you enter middle school, your brains will enter a new era of development. Your brains will become more malleable—that means they’ll be like a block of clay softening up so they can be resculpted. Scientists call this “brain plasticity.” The first period of brain plasticity is from ages 0 to 3, when our brains [grow rapidly](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK234146/). We create new billions of brain cells and neural connections. But this second period of plasticity, between 11 and 14, is when our neural connections are reorganized.1 **>> Timeline: 0 to 3 + 11 to 14** The brain reorganization happens because your brains become highly sensitive to what we experience, both good and bad. One experience that is [especially heightened](https://www.nature.com/articles/nature25770) is social interactions. During this period, we are more sensitive to social acceptance and rejection. So hanging out with friends *feels* better than it does at other points in our lives, while being rejected or bullied feels worse. These experiences rewire our brains; some neural connections get stronger, while others are cut off. **>> Diagram** Meanwhile, your brains will also develop a greater capacity for [self-direction](https://nap.nationalacademies.org/catalog/25388/the-promise-of-adolescence-realizing-opportunity-for-all-youth). So you’ll want more autonomy on what to wear, what to say, and how to spend their time.
1 Developmental psychologist Laurence Steinberg writes quite accessibly about this brain plasticity in his book "[Age of Opportunity.](https://www.laurencesteinberg.com/books/age-of-opportunity).”
Hey, fifth-graders, let’s take a trip to middle school to visit sixth-graders.
Hey, sixth-graders—how’s it going?
Honestly, not great.
Hmm, OK. Well I asked fifth-graders how much they feel like they <label>belong in school</label>. How are you doing in sixth grade?
Whoa. Sixth-graders feel way less . What’s wrong?
We switched schools, and our friendships got all messed up.
I loved my fifth-grade teacher. Now I have a different teacher for each subject.
There’s no recess and our breaks are so short. So we never get to just hang out.
OK let’s see how seventh-graders are doing. Who feels like they <label>belong in their school</label>?

Oh. Things don’t get better for seventh graders.


Can I ask some more questions?
Sure. Whatever.
Who feels <label>engaged in school</label>?
Who has a good <label>relationship with your teachers</label>?
Who thinks the <label>school climate</label> is good? As in, your teachers are excited; the physical space is nice; and the rules are fair?
The rules are completely made up to make us miserable.
Who has <label>supportive relationships</label>?
It’s definitely not our teachers, though.
Who frequently experienced <label>positive feelings</label> in the past week?
OK, middle school sucks royally. Why does it even exist?

Great question. Around 1900, most school districts had one school for kindergarten to 8th grade. But everyone from [college presidents](https://www.tojned.net/journals/tojned/articles/v04i01/v04i01-01.pdf) to the [National Education Association](https://www.rand.org/pubs/monographs/MG139.html) argued that seventh graders should be attend a school that prepares them for high school: junior high school. **>> Diagram** However, what really pushed school districts to adopt junior high schools was overcrowding. People moved to cities because that’s where there were new jobs for adults, and immigrants also came from other countries and moved to cities. So K-8 schools were super crowded.1 So taking the older kids out of elementary school and putting them in junior high made practical sense. During this era, the number of junior highs skyrocketed. **>> Chart | Need data (rise of junior highs)** Junior high was [basically](https://archive.org/details/educatingyoungad0000unse_q0p1/page/36/mode/2up?q=Mounting+Dissatisfaction) high school for younger kids, so in the 1960s [people who study education](https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/pdf/10.1080/19404476.2016.1165036) wanted to replace junior highs with something that actually considers what people your age need—things like smaller group learning, better relationships with teachers, and more exploration. They called it middle school. Slowly, more and more districts adopted the middle school model. **>> Chart | [NCES](https://nces.ed.gov/programs/digest/d10/tables/dt10_097.asp)**
1 The RAND Corporation published a fantastic [book](https://www.rand.org/pubs/monographs/MG139.html) on the history of middle schools, which covers this in more depth.
Cool story, bro. But it’s still miserable.
I know, I know. I’ll explain more soon. But wanna see how 8th graders and high school kids are doing?
Yes! I can’t wait for high school.
Sorry to break it to you. But in high school, <label>school engagement</label> falls even further.
Very few students have strong <label>relationships with teachers</label>.
And your <label>sense of belonging</label>? It stays low.
Seriously? It doesn’t get better?
I mean, it actually does improve a bit, especially later in high school.
I say we get rid of middle schools!

So, you’re not the first person to have that idea.


Research out of [New York](https://www.educationnext.org/stuck-in-the-middle/), [Florida](https://www.educationnext.org/the-middle-school-plunge/), and [several other](https://ies.ed.gov/ncee/edlabs/regions/west/Ask/Details/53) areas found that kids who attend middle schools learned less, while feeling lower levels of belonging and self esteem, when compared to kids who attend K-8 schools. 


**>> Chart of some research**


So some school districts went back to K-8 schools. 


But [other research](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0094119018300081) showed that, when you’re a fifth-grader in a K-8 school, you actually struggle more because you’re mixed with older kids. And then you catch up as you get to the [top dogs](https://journals.sagepub.com/stoken/rbtfl/5rYuHMOFCG3nc/full) in your school. So by the 8th grade, you [same place](https://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/10.1086/498996).


**>> Chart of above research**


So there’s pros and cons to middle schools. But the most important part is that the schools realize that you’re going through a lot at this point in your lives.
I’m going to go back to the middle-school kids, OK?
Tell Ms. Kowalski I said hi! I had her in sixth grade!
OK, I’m back!
Hi. Middle school still sucks, btw.
I know, I know. But I wanted to tell you…
Wait, did *you* even like middle school?
Honestly, no. But at the time, I thought something was wrong with me.
Like what? Were you, like, a nerd?
Yes. I *loved* Pokemon, so I guess I spent most of my time thinking about how to evolve my Bulbasaur.
Just look it up on the internet! It’s so easy!
This was before most people had the internet… actually, nevermind. Yes, I was a nerd.
I like Pokemon, too! So am I, like, mid-evolution? Like, I just have to evolve to be a high-schooler?
Actually, I think that’s the problem. We treat you like you’re in an awkward growing stage. But this stage of your life is incredibly important.

I read a book1 written by scientists, and they said your brain is not an “advanced” child brain or “immature” adult brain. It’s just doing what it needs for you, right now.
1 The [National Academy of Sciences book](https://nap.nationalacademies.org/catalog/25388/the-promise-of-adolescence-realizing-opportunity-for-all-youth) published a great summary of the latest research on adolescent brain development.
Great. Even my brain is making me miserable.
Well, we—adults—aren’t putting you in the best environments.
Oh, I know. Trust me.
Sorry.
It’s OK. But will things get better?
Yeah… yeah, I think it will.
Cool. Well, I hope you’re not just saying that.
Yeah, me too.

text:
We’re learning that middle school has a huge effect on the rest of our lives. After all, it’s the period of our lives when our brains open up to the world—to feel more happiness, more sadness, more everything. The world we curate around middle-school kids shapes who they’ll become.


But maybe even that should take a back seat to what middle-schoolers are telling us: This isn’t working for us.
